About Venues - Yeongang Gallery

A GROUNDBREAKING ART GALLERY NEAR THE NORTH-SOUTH KOREAN BORDER
Above the South Korean Civilian Control Line, 
which runs alongside the Demilitarized Zone (commonly known as the DMZ), the gallery is the first of its kind to open near the heavily armed border.
The Korean DMZ seems like an unlikely place to find contemporary art. Yet, 
the Yeongang Art Gallery is perched on the edge of it, in an area known as Yeoncheon county. The gallery exhibits art from around the world and serves as a concert venue. 
"It's extremely interesting to see the contrast between the military and the geography here 
Since the ceasefire in 1953, to enter the Civilian Control Zone in Yeoncheon, all visitors should go through a guard post. In a short moment when sentries check our ID cards and the number of visitors, we leave one reality and enter another. After running through the uninhabited CCZ, we reach the Yeongang Gallery, which was renovated from a building used as a security museum and opened in June 2016. It is the first art space established in the CCZ in 60 years. "Yeongang" is another name for the Imjingang River. 
https://edition.cnn.com/style/article/yeongang-...
https://ggc.ggcf.kr/p/5b5b43687a74c422d68411f1
 
About Venues -Suwon Museum of Art

Suwon I’Park Museum of Art was established in 2015 in the plaza of the Hwaseong Haenggung Palace, which was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site. 
Suwon is home to one of Korea’s representative cultural heritage landmarks, the Hwaseong Fortress The museum sought to establish the identity and cultural development of Suwon arts and form a cultural space where the citizens of Suwon can enjoy high-quality exhibitions. Suwon Museum of Art aims to develop Suwon’s art culture through various exhibitions and educational programs that reinterpret Suwon’s historicity and cultural symbolism in a modern sense.
Facilities 
The museum has total 5 galleries, gallery 1, 2 and 3 on the ground floor and gallery 4 and 5 on the second floor. The contemporary art in various kinds of genres is presented in the galleries.
https://sima.suwon.go.kr/eng/index.do

story:
Happiness. The small cheerful memories of the past that we hold onto.
Sadness. The hurt reflected in the mirror when we take those breaths to stay calm.
Fear. The nagging worries that threaten to pull us undone.
Surprise. The emotion that can turn from wonder to horror in a heartbeat.
Anger. The fiery bitterness of wounds that never seem to close. 
Disgust. The disappointment and judgement of actions done. 

In the 1970s, psychologist Paul Eckman pointed to these six emotions as those that lie at the root of all emotional action and reactions. Much like in real life, the characters in our favorite tales are, at their core, compelled by these feelings.

Today, join us as we venture into the storytelling of The Dragon Prince to paint an illustrative homage to our favorite characters; let's make this book a reality!

Echoes of Thunder is a 200+ page art anthology that features works from 75 contributors from around the globe. The book is a celebration of The Dragon Prince and its characters, who we follow on various adventures in the hit Netflix series. 

While looking at both major and minor characters, each illustrator was assigned one of the six core emotions and asked to show us how the series depicted that emotion in a character of their choice. From there, we worked with each of them to cultivate a visual narrative showcasing the various aspects of the scene.

Whether you're new to The Dragon Prince fandom or have been following since the first glimpses of dragons made their way onto the internet, we welcome you to join us on this artistic journey and hope you'll support us. To see more previews and info, feel free to follow us on: Twitter, Tumblr (anthology specific), Instagram or Facebook.

All  design and art is subject to change.

The project features over 100 full color illustrations, organized by emotion and supplemented with artist commentaries and introductory passages discussing each core feeling and its importance. At the current funding level, the book is 7"x9.3", full color on all pages. It is designed to be standard (8.5"x11.3") or oversized (9"x12") if we hit enough funding. You can see that and more stretch goal details farther down in the campaign.

You can get merchandise in one of two ways in the campaign: You can get a bundle that includes what you want now or you can buy the base book and add items on during the surveys. (Note for the U.S.: To add merchandise, you can't buy the Echoes of Thunder [Bait] tier version of the book; it has reduced shipping costs but can only ship the book.)

We partner with BackerKit, a company that helps with backer support, and will be doing surveys (including add-ons) in the weeks following the campaign. We'll send out all the info you need in updates. TL;DR: You don't have to add these now unless you want the 21/15% discount for everything with the free gift box (Startouched Tier). 

The merchandise list below is for your reference. They're unlimited, but many are Indiegogo exclusives (as noted):

•  Postcards (Standard): Campaign Exclusive: Callum & Ezran (designed by Golden Rose), Gren & Amaya (designed by Rusavia), Soren & Claudia (designed by Botanica), Rayla & Runaan (designed by Ghost), Viren & Aaravos (designed by Ale) 
•  Postcards (Specialty): Campaign Exclusive: CMYK-foiled set (stretch goal unlocks!)
•  Individual Stickers (Vinyl): Campaign Exclusive: Soren & Claudia (designed by Allexche), Zym's Egg & Potion (designed by Caroline Chiou), Dark Tome & Zym (designed by Brighan) (all stretch goal unlocks)
•  Sticker Sheets: Campaign Exclusive: Characters (designed by Ji) or Objects (designed by Caroline Chiou)
•  Enamel Pins: Campaign Exclusive Pricing: Bait (and any color variations we unlock), Zym, Primal Stone (Glitter), Phoe-Phoe (Glow-in-the-dark) (designed by Mel & Sara)
•  Charms (Double-sided clear, 2.5"): Claudia (design by Reneissance), Rayla (designed by Sara/Qesque), Aaravos (designed by Kairoseur)
•  Poster Print: Campaign Exclusive Price: Aaravos (designed by Lizzart)
•  Giclee Print: Campaign Exclusive: Aaravos (Lizzart), Sol Regem (designed by Mike Nash) – giclee museum print, made with archival inks (never fades with time)
•  Gift Box: Campaign Exclusive: Custom-designed pencil-box-sized merchandise holder (designed by Kay Fine)

--> Please note that digital PDFs are not considered merch. They are sold separately in the survey for an extra charge.

The project wouldn't be possible without the fantastic 75 contributors who have worked tirelessly through concepts and numerous artwork reviews, constantly cheering each other on to get to where we are now. From artists who have worked on The Dragon Prince themselves to fans from the community to members of Alchemy, we're here to present you with our best.

Alphabetically: 7CLUBS  |  Aclyr  |  Alba Palacio  |  Ale*  |  Allexche*  |  Amy Stoddard  |  Andrea Demori  |  Angel1802  |  Aquanut  |  Arandanity  |  Azoria Wolf  |  Botanica*  |  Brighan Cernunnos*  |  Caroline Chiou*  |  Chamille "Rin" Mies  |  Chilkat  |  CHRISQI  |  Cortez  |  Crimson Chains  |  Dagos  |  Dani Kruse  |  Delaney Januzzi  |  DiesVitae  |  eerna   |  Elentori  |  Elimnebe  |  Enorae  |  FadingJade  |  Favrocious  |  fconvicted  |  gesuko  |  Ghost-Kaiju  |  godliath  |  Golden Rose*  |  Htg17  |  Jelly  |  Ji*  |  Josephine Frayling  |  Kairoseur*  |  Karolina "Isvoc" Plutowska*  |  katalean  |  Kay Fine*  |  Leaf  |  Lesly Oh  |  Lizzart*  |  Maarta Laiho  |  meru  |  Mike Nash  |  Milky  |  Mona May  |  Nekojiima  |  Oliver Lutro  |  Owlma  |  Palu  |  Prince Lowell  |  Reneissance*  |  Rusavia*  |  Sffau  |  Shahina  |  Shibara  |  Shino  |  Shunkaku  |  Silver Kontus  |  Simsamy  |  Sleepsunn  |  Valuiss  |  Velinxi  |  Viera Boudreau (Aloeviera)  |  Yael G. Blanco  |  Yakitty  |  Yanli Wang

Cover art: Sara "Qesque" Squires
Special postcard pieces: Dorothy Yang & Hanna
Writing & editing: Amala & Incendium

Organizing, Art Direction and Production: Mel "Zorav" Sayre, Sara "Qesque" Squires & Jessica "Thunderpot"

* names above: produced additional merchandise.

Please view the chart below (feel free to click the image if you'd like to view it at a larger scale) or look at the listings to the right for details on what's provided in each of the tiers! Note that limited tiers are limited and usually can't be restocked for production reasons.

Goals will be added as previous ones are met! When noted, store unlocks (such as the pin designs) are items added in the post-campaign store, while additions (such as CMYK foiled postcards and stickers) are added for all applicable tiers within the campaign.

The giveaway is now closed and the winners have been emailed. Thank you to everyone who participated!

Referral Rewards:

As a thanks for sharing our campaign, the top three people with the most referrals will be granted a $40, $20 and $10 credit to the store. Please see the blurb below for notes on referral tracking from Indiegogo:

For a backer to count as a referrer, they must promote your campaign with Indiegogo’s share tools while logged into their Indiegogo account. This is important because otherwise, their unique ID won’t be attached to any resulting contributions or visits.

At Alchemy Art, supporting the community we work with is one of our primary goals, along with continuing to push creatives to grow and offer them new opportunities. Our hope is that we always give back something in the projects we create, whether it be for charity (which we've donated just under $50,000 to-date) or working with other professionals in our community.

With approval from The Dragon Prince team, this project is for-profit, supporting the creators in the process. The Dragon Prince team has always been supportive of creative efforts, and that's something we hope to honor with this endeavor. We truly seek to make a memorable book that's both a collector's item and an exciting experience for the reader.

Note: The breakdown for 500 books is above. In the 500 book breakdown pictured, the owners & art directors of Alchemy Art aren't paid for their efforts (which amount to several thousand hours cumulatively). These are the primary items that are funded first to make sure the project is funded successfully.

To the best of our ability, we'll adhere to the timetable! Our hope is to have items in during the early portion of November and start getting the items moving out mid-November. (Barring any extreme situations, all books should be received by Christmas!)

As with any large project, there are always potential problems with working with many contributors and many different manufacturers. We're grateful to be working with all manufacturers that we have used before for this project, and we're confident of their quality and our mutual expectations.

In that, almost all of our artwork for the Echoes of Thunder book is complete; the items that remain are finalizing the book designs and doing a few test runs. We don't anticipate any delays in pushing the book to production or seeing any of the merchandise sent to the printers (once the project funds, we'll be okaying test pieces!). 

We work with BackerKit for post-campaign fulfilment and PrintNinja for our main set of custom books. 

All in all, we always strive to be fully transparent and forthcoming about any issues, and will always update when we have enough information to pass along.

If you have any issues at any time, please feel free to reach out to us at alchemyartgroup@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary

Throughout my entire career as an artist, books have been important to me. I made miniature "books" as a child and graduated into zinemaking and handmade books. I used to go to the bookstore with my late grandfather and absolutely marvel at the pages surrounding me. Making books felt like a natural fit both as an artist and as a photographer. I made a number of artist books in college that were very successful, including my senior thesis project. Books have always felt like the perfect space for my photography and writing to come together.

I am passionate about this project. I have been working on it nonstop for months and feel I have created some of the strongest imagery I have ever made and that it melds beautifully with the writing component of the project as well. Unfortunately, due to limited resources, handmaking the book is not practical at this time. I have partnered with Conveyor Arts to come up with a beautiful proof that I am excited to make into reality. The costs of book production are expensive and frankly, I need help. This is where y'all come in.

Artist Statement

ca·dence (‘kādns): a modulation or inflection of the voice; a modulation in reading aloud as implied by the structure and ordering of words and phrases in written text; a fall in pitch of the voice at the end of a phrase or sentence; rhythm.

This project describes an existential crisis at 3 AM following a stoned orgasm. It chronologically follows a train of thought in the form of text-to-speech notes on an iPhone. Save for punctuation and spelling, these notes are unedited.

What I Need & What You Get

I am looking for $600 to self-publish my book through Conveyor Arts. This will pay for all the production costs associated with the book. I am offering many perk options for those who donate, including stickers from this project, postcards, and preorder copies of the book itself, as well as copies of my other releases. This is a really great opportunity to both support me as an artist and be the owner of some of my work.

The Impact

I struggled to find my place in the world after graduation. I threw myself into the world of bartending and took a break from creating art, but I was not as happy as I could be. While I am still bartending to support myself, I have really dedicated myself to my practice in the last few months and am very proud of what I am creating.  It has been hard to make ends meet as it is, and the idea of publishing this book seemed like a luxury. I have a hard time asking people for help; it was only after an overwhelming response on Instagram that I decided that I wanted to open this project up for donations.

Risks & Challenges

Thankfully, because I am not printing and binding myself this time around, there are very few risks and challenges involved. The quote I have recieved from Conveyor is thorough and I have all of my costs laid out in front of me.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to donate, I ask that you spread this link as widely as you can for increased visibility! It means more than you know.

story:
Pre-orders available in our online store!
https://ruefish.com/exposure-coins

----------------------------------

Stop me if you've heard this one before:

You are a baker - a friend of an acquaintance asks you to bake her dream wedding cake for free. Don't worry, she'll tell the guests all about you!

You are a graphic designer - your uncle's best friend's nephew asks you to design his logo, free of charge.  But don't worry, he's gonna pin a few on the board at the local coffee shop with all the other cards - everyone will see it and the exposure will be great!

You are a comic artist - some random person on the internet demands you draw their dog dressed up as a superhero for free. They promise to show their friends.  WHY DO YOU WANT MONEY? WHERE IS YOUR PASSION? WHY DO YOU HATE DOGS? WhAtEvEr YoUr WoRk IsNt EvEn tHaT gOoD loL.

And the list goes on.

Of course, requests and expectations of working for nothing more than exposure is not limited to creative professionals. You'll hear some of the same lamentations from people in a variety of trades - plumbers, accountants, mechanics and more. Word of mouth is great and so very important, but exposure does not pay the bills! The Exposure Coin won't pay the bills either, but it will at least give you a laugh, help you remember your value, and give you a little something to clench your fist around the next time someone asks!

The first design in The Exposure Coin™ line of novelty coins was made available for online purchase in the beginning of August.  There are currently two designs available: the original design (left) that started it all and Liberty (right), featuring a partial pressing of Ron Landis' Liberty Skull!

If you've ever tried to pay a bill in exposure, you know how well it works: it doesn't. Working for exposure stinks.  It's senseless.  No, wait.  It's cents-less.  If you had a penny for every time someone asked, you'd probably be a little better off.

Our newest Exposure Coin design: Cented!

Above: Mock-up of the next design

Cented features an aluminum ring with a US cent encased in the center.  Along with Cented, we're releasing Uncented: an identical aluminum design without an encased cent!  (We offer no apologies for our absolutely shameless word-play).

Many of our customers know about our penchant for vintage machines and souvenirs. From buttons to bracelets, they've inspired our work from the beginning.  Coins have been no different - so it should come as no surprise that we looked to vintage encased cents and lucky coins for inspiration!

Encased coins began showing up as souvenirs in 1901. Their production and popularity peaked after World War II into the 50s with the end of wartime conservation efforts, and the increased availability of inexpensive aluminum and other metals.

Both Cented and Uncented will be made using a 32mm (~1.25") aluminum ring approximately 2mm (~5/64") thick. We think it's the perfect size - small enough to keep in your pocket, but large enough to not be mistaken for the loose change and lost.  All Cented Exposure Coins have one US cent encased in the center. Just for this campaign, we are only using pennies that are 95% copper.

With the exception of 1943, cents minted from 1900 through 1981 are what we're looking to encase in the perks that we send out through this campaign. Don't get too excited, we seriously doubt we'll end up with many pennies more than 50 or so years old. Why the emphasis on copper content? Fun fact: the copper content in the pennies we're using are actually worth more than a penny! We think that makes the concept behind this design just a little more fun, and the extra sorting and possible expense in pursuit of this little chuckle is the least we can do to say thanks for the support!

We press the design into the aluminum at the same time we insert the cent. It's the pressure in the production process that causes the metal to flow and lock the penny in place. The penny encased within a Cented is not going anywhere without a whole lot of effort, probable destruction of the aluminum encasement, and possible injury. The penny is not meant to be removed: do not try to remove it. Any attempt to remove the penny is done at your risk.

Early Exposure
You get both Cented  with a US cent encased in the center and Uncented with the cent missing!  As an early backer, you also get an extra thick version of The Exposure Coin™ that got the party started!  Each coin is packaged in a protective pouch.

Encase of Exposure (unlocked once Early Exposure runs out)
You get both Cented with a US cent encased in the center as well as Uncented  with the cent missing!

Centsational Exposure
If you're looking to get a few coins, this is the perk for you!  You get a three pack of Cented and Uncented.

Overexposed
Wanna make it rain Exposure?  Snag this perk!  You get a ten pack of Cented and Uncented. 
 

Each coin is made manually, one by one in our shop and we work in small batches, which is why reward tiers are marked with limited availability. We will open up new perks with later delivery dates if perks with earlier delivery dates sell out.

The Exposure Coin™ is an ongoing product line and project. Any funds remaining beyond the completion and delivery of this design will be put toward continued development of The Exposure Coin product line and associated activities.  It's more than just merch, it's a mission and a movement!

15 October 2019: Campaign Ends

~1 November 2019

  • funds released
  • final die production begins
  • supplies ordered

~15 November 2019

  • Coin production begins

~2 December 2019

  • Backer Survey sent

~13 December 2019

  • perks begin shipping


Risks & Challenges

Risks are minimal.

The trial and error phase is already completed - production is just a matter of funding and pushing play on the processes we have in place. The design is ready to go and our supply order is ready to be submitted. This is our first time on Indiegogo, but this is our 4th crowdfunding campaign.  We have a history of on-time or early delivery through both crowdfunding campaigns and our regular operations. This is our 8th coin design and all have been produced in-house. Most of the funding will support die production.

We've already begun sorting through rolls of pennies from the bank. We are prepared for the additional expense of purchasing pre-sorted pennies to maintain our timeline.

As soon as this project is fully funded, we will immediately move forward with full production. Creating several "functional" versions of the Cented design in advance of launching the project has allowed us to not only nail down specifics involved in production of the product, but has also enabled us to get a firm handle on shipping requirements. We anticipate a timeline of approximately 6-8 weeks from campaign close for production, packaging and shipping. Answering your backer surveys in a timely fashion will help us to stay on track in getting rewards shipped to you.

Our goal is to begin shipping no later than the second week of December, however our timeline allows for minor shipping delays for the remaining supplies. Backers will be notified immediately in cases of significant challenges and will be otherwise updated on a weekly basis.People value your transparency.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone is in a position to support this project financially, and that's okay!  Here are some other ways you can help us cross the finish line:

  • Make some noise! Get the word out about our campaign, every single "share" boosts the signal!
  • Follow us on social media and let us know what you think of the project!
story_txt:
Pre-orders available in our online store!https://ruefish.com/exposure-coins

----------------------------------
Stop me if you've heard this one before:
You are a baker - a friend of an acquaintance asks you to bake her dream wedding cake for free. Don't worry, she'll tell the guests all about you!
You are a graphic designer - your uncle's best friend's nephew asks you to design his logo, free of charge.  But don't worry, he's gonna pin a few on the board at the local coffee shop with all the other cards - everyone will see it and the exposure will be great!
You are a comic artist - some random person on the internet demands you draw their dog dressed up as a superhero for free. They promise to show their friends.  WHY DO YOU WANT MONEY? WHERE IS YOUR PASSION? WHY DO YOU HATE DOGS? WhAtEvEr YoUr WoRk IsNt EvEn tHaT gOoD loL.
And the list goes on.
Of course, requests and expectations of working for nothing more than exposure is not limited to creative professionals. You'll hear some of the same lamentations from people in a variety of trades - plumbers, accountants, mechanics and more. Word of mouth is great and so very important, but exposure does not pay the bills! The Exposure Coin won't pay the bills either, but it will at least give you a laugh, help you remember your value, and give you a little something to clench your fist around the next time someone asks!

The first design in The Exposure Coin™ line of novelty coins was made available for online purchase in the beginning of August.  There are currently two designs available: the original design (left) that started it all and Liberty (right), featuring a partial pressing of Ron Landis' Liberty Skull!
If you've ever tried to pay a bill in exposure, you know how well it works: it doesn't. Working for exposure stinks.  It's senseless.  No, wait.  It's cents-less.  If you had a penny for every time someone asked, you'd probably be a little better off.
Our newest Exposure Coin design: Cented!

Above: Mock-up of the next design
Cented features an aluminum ring with a US cent encased in the center.  Along with Cented, we're releasing Uncented: an identical aluminum design without an encased cent!  (We offer no apologies for our absolutely shameless word-play).

Many of our customers know about our penchant for vintage machines and souvenirs. From buttons to bracelets, they've inspired our work from the beginning.  Coins have been no different - so it should come as no surprise that we looked to vintage encased cents and lucky coins for inspiration!
Encased coins began showing up as souvenirs in 1901. Their production and popularity peaked after World War II into the 50s with the end of wartime conservation efforts, and the increased availability of inexpensive aluminum and other metals.
Both Cented and Uncented will be made using a 32mm (~1.25") aluminum ring approximately 2mm (~5/64") thick. We think it's the perfect size - small enough to keep in your pocket, but large enough to not be mistaken for the loose change and lost.  All Cented Exposure Coins have one US cent encased in the center. Just for this campaign, we are only using pennies that are 95% copper.
With the exception of 1943, cents minted from 1900 through 1981 are what we're looking to encase in the perks that we send out through this campaign. Don't get too excited, we seriously doubt we'll end up with many pennies more than 50 or so years old. Why the emphasis on copper content? Fun fact: the copper content in the pennies we're using are actually worth more than a penny! We think that makes the concept behind this design just a little more fun, and the extra sorting and possible expense in pursuit of this little chuckle is the least we can do to say thanks for the support!
We press the design into the aluminum at the same time we insert the cent. It's the pressure in the production process that causes the metal to flow and lock the penny in place. The penny encased within a Cented is not going anywhere without a whole lot of effort, probable destruction of the aluminum encasement, and possible injury. The penny is not meant to be removed: do not try to remove it. Any attempt to remove the penny is done at your risk.

Early ExposureYou get both Cented  with a US cent encased in the center and Uncented with the cent missing!  As an early backer, you also get an extra thick version of The Exposure Coin™ that got the party started!  Each coin is packaged in a protective pouch.
Encase of Exposure (unlocked once Early Exposure runs out)You get both Cented with a US cent encased in the center as well as Uncented  with the cent missing!
Centsational ExposureIf you're looking to get a few coins, this is the perk for you!  You get a three pack of Cented and Uncented.
OverexposedWanna make it rain Exposure?  Snag this perk!  You get a ten pack of Cented and Uncented.  
Each coin is made manually, one by one in our shop and we work in small batches, which is why reward tiers are marked with limited availability. We will open up new perks with later delivery dates if perks with earlier delivery dates sell out.
The Exposure Coin™ is an ongoing product line and project. Any funds remaining beyond the completion and delivery of this design will be put toward continued development of The Exposure Coin product line and associated activities.  It's more than just merch, it's a mission and a movement!

~1 November 2019

~13 December 2019
perks begin shipping

The design is ready to go and our supply order is ready to be submitted. story:
My son Jack, 10, is working on his first interactive art project to bring to Burining Man. We have a plan in place and developed some of the initial elements, but he is looking for support to cover material costs. I'm excited to help him bring his project to life, while teaching him about art, technology and community. 

At a very high level, it will function as follows. As one walks up to the art piece, they will see a sign with instructions, a box with crystals and a large wooden crate. As one places their hand above mystic gemstones, it will kick off the magic. In the wooden crate will be 3 large eggs inside of a nest, with two hatching dragons. There will be roars, animatronics, smoke and more fun. It should be a lot of fun. 

Thanks in advance for any support you can give. We hope you like the video!

Our Fundraising Goal

  • In our project plan, we have calculated needing $300-500 to make the project happen. The extra money will help support more fun stuff.
  • Even if we don't hit that target on indiegogo, your support will help the project!
  • Donations will be spent on wood, metal, electronic components, etc.

Risks & Challenges

  • Burning Man may not happen this year (but hopefully it does). If it doesn't we will bring the art piece next year
  • Kids may not be able to attend, due to the state of the vaccination rules and testing. If that is the case we may defer bringing the piece to 2022. I would let my son decide. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you like the video or project, please feel free to send it to friends!
  • Indiegogo has great SHARE tools

Thank you!

story:
+= 

We are Andrea Chiu and Katie Chung of A-O-K Studio. With degrees from The School of the Art Institute of Chicago, we are both practicing artists and designers. This summer we have been invited to teach a graphic design class to Haitian artists at the Jakmel Ekspresyon Center in Jacmel, Haiti. Directed by Sue Frame, The Jakmel Ekspresyon Center is non-profit artists space that dedicates itself to making art accessible to the Jakmel community. This two week course will equip each student with the skills necessary to use up-to-date design software and to communicate graphically with the rest of the world.


 

A-O-K Studio (L>R: Jing Ouyang, Andrea Chiu, Katie Chung)   

  

                                                                 

Painting students at the JE Center


We would like to raise money to cover the cost of our airfare and lodging in Jacmel. 

We are teaching as volunteers and are taking this project on at our own expense. Overall, it is going to cost us just over $500.00 each for airfare and about $450.00 to lodge both of us at a hotel in Jacmel. With the JE Center we have found the means to put together materials for the class. Your support will bring us there and back -- helping us focus on why we are going in the first place, and that is to teach a skill that Haitian artists have asked to learn. We believe that in return this opportunity will allow us to share what we know, gain teaching experience, connect us with Haitian artists, and overall show us an entirely different part of the world. 
To thank you for your contribution we have collaborated on a series of screen printed tote bags, satin patches, and postcards.  


Patterns by Andrea & Katie for the tote bags and patches 

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything is a worthy contribution to us, if you are not financially capable of donating, please spread the word about our project to those you think would be interested. Thank you! 


Links

Jakmel Ekspresyon Center: http://jecenter.org/
Andrea Chiu: http://arcexponential.com/
Katie Chung: http://katiechung.com/

Thank you for your time and support !

story:
About this project

We would like to establish more dormitory facilities which can be used for 30,000JPY per month in order to support starting out animators!

Hello. My name is Jun Sugawara of the Animator Supporting Organization.

This project is aimed to set up more dormitory facilities that animators who are new to the industry can use for 30,000JPY per month(including utility expenses). The animators who get to use the [Starting Out Animators’ Dormitory] will also get chances for social exchanges beyond the boundaries of companies, and also receive technical support for illustrations and drawing. Currently, we are supporting 2 starting out animators at the dorm. For this project, we aim to expand the dorm facility up to 2 times the current scale.

But as we are short in managing funds in order to expand the dorm facilities, we would like to ask for your kind support.



Animation content has gained worldwide popularity, and for Japan, it is also an industry where the contents can be exported without importing any resources since Japan is a country which lacks in natural resources.

Even now, many animation shows are shown on TV and in theaters, and there are also many people who say they love watching Anime. But behind that shiny center stage, the average salary of animators in their 20’s are said to be just around 90,000JPY per month. (※1)

The reason why the earnings are so drastically low despite of the hard labor, overtime, holiday shifts at almost every field of work, is because in most cases, animators are hired and paid according to the piece-work system(※2) based on the price per each frame an animator draws, and it takes time to become a skillful animator who can draw quicker and cover more frames within the given time, to have a fair amount of earnings per month.



Also, many animation studios are mostly located in Tokyo(※especially in the Suginami and Nerima districts), and the high monthly cost for rent in Tokyo becomes a greater burden for starting out animators who come to Tokyo from other regions in Japan. (So they are in a state where they have to pay high rent in Tokyo to live, despite of their low income)

※1) According to the research on the current situation(answered by 728 people) announced by the Japan Animation Creators Association(JAniCA) in 2009 states that the average monthly income of animators in their 20’s is a bit more than 90,000JPY. Which makes it around 1,100,000JPY on an yearly basis.

※2) In the case of TV series, the price for inbetweens is 200JPY per piece(when the work is done under prime contract). So if an animator draws 300 pieces per month, the monthly income is 300 pieces × 200JPY = 60,000JPY. But it is especially difficult for a starting out animator to draw 300 pieces per month. Also, as animation work is time-consuming, it is not likely to have part-time jobs on the side.



To address this matter, the NPO Animator Supporting Organization has opened the 1st [Starting Out Animators’ Dormitory] in March 2014, where starting out animators can stay for just 30,000JPY per month(including utility expenses), and also get chances for social exchanges beyond the boundaries of companies, and receive technical support for illustrations and drawing from veteran animators.


What we are planning now, is to expand this to a new facility that can house 2~3 people. The location is expected to be in Asagaya, Suginami district. We will rent a 3LDK room and modify it to use as a dormitory.

[9,200USD for opening a new dormitory]
-Deposit / Key money / Monthly rent in advance / Rent security deposit / 7,500USD
-Real estate brokerage fee / 1500USD
-General security insurance for residential lease / 200USD
[3,800USD for production cost on goods in return, etc. ]
-Production cost for goods in return / 3,500USD
-Shipping cost for goods in return / 300USD (+αif there are many shipments to overseas)
[2,300USD for READYFOR Commission charge. ]
-READYFOR Commission charge 15%

[So we need a total of 15,000USD]

By opening a dormitory with low rent rates, we are able to set up an environment where animators who are starting out in the industry can concentrate on their work without worrying about their everyday living, and also have a place to support them gain new know-how and acquire techniques required at their field of work in order to quickly earn more at their jobs.




[NPO Animator Supporting Organization : Achievements]

・Holding Grand Prix for starting out animators

  http://animator.main.jp/prize_2015.html

  This is our 4th year for this contest. Until now, we have supported 5 animators with 600,000JPY as [Residence Support Fund] for the past 3 years.

・Operating dormitory for starting out animators

  http://animator.main.jp/dormitory_2014.html

  We have opened the 1st dormitory of the [Starting Out Animators’ Dormitory] on March, 2014. Currently, we are providing residential support to 2 starting out animators. With the current project, we are aiming to expand the facility to 2 times the current scale.

(Interior of the 1st Dormitory opened on March 2014)


・Holding animation workshops

  http://animator.main.jp/workshop_2014_001.html

  We think that it would be nice to have an environment where many active animators and applicants who want to be a part of the anime production, can have a more direct contact and exchanges with each other. But as the system management and operations required for such environment is tremendous, in reality it is difficult for an average animator to try such a thing by oneself.

  Therefore the Animator Supporting Organization is thinking of being in the position to take over that troublesome “Management & Operations” part, to develop an environment where animators can find it easy to come and give lectures, and also create a ‘Platform’ where many animators can have easy access to.

  ※The Starting Out Animators’ Dormitory users can attend the Anime Workshops for free of charge.


[About the Perks]

[Perks for 150USD support]

・300USD worth of exchange coupon plus,

・[The 1st Starting Out Animators’ Grand Prix / Catalogue] ×1 copy

  (32 pages / Color 2 pages)

・[The 2nd Starting Out Animators’ Grand Prix / Catalogue] ×1 copy

  (32 pages / Color 2 pages)

・[The 3rd Starting Out Animators’ Grand Prix / Catalogue] ×1 copy

  (32 pages / Color 2 pages)



[Perks for 300USD support]

・150USD worth of exchange coupon plus,

・[The 4th Starting Out Animators’ Grand Prix / Catalog] ×1 copy

  (32 pages / Color 2 pages)

・The 4th Animator Award Winner Tokuda will draw you into an anime character!

[Exchange Coupons for 500USD support]

・300USD worth of exchange coupon plus,

・[Boarders’ Diary 2014 Edition] ×1 copy

  (32 pages / Color 2 pages)


[Perk for 1,000USD support]

・500USD worth of exchange coupon plus,

・[Starting Out Animators’ Dormitory Report / Illustration Book・2014 Edition] ×1 copy

  (32 pages / Color 10 pages)


Illustration by : Kiyotaka Oshiyama

Illustration by : Yoshimichi Kameda


Comic by : Naoyuki Asano

※In the [Starting Out Animators’ Dormitory Report / Illustration Book・2014 Edition], illustrations by , Kiyotaka Oshiyama, Yoshimichi Kameyama, Naoyuki Asano, Shingo Tamagawa's art are planned to be included

・[Starting Out Animators’ Dormitory Report / Illustration Original Drawing] ×1 piece

One of the original drawings for the [Starting Out Animators’ Dormitory Report / Illustration Book・2014 Edition] shown above will be presented!


Illustration by : Shingo Tamagawa

Thank you for reading through!

Please show us your generous support on the project!

story:
Hi, you may know me, I am Lawrence Dinkins (or NSAA to my poetry friends). I am an underground art and cultural archivist. I am a local Sacramento poet that is a co-host at Jose Montoya's Poetry Unplugged, Mahogany Urban Poetry Series and 3rd Thursday Lunch Hour Poetry at the Central Library. I also have three podcast: Black Talk Sacramento, Coffee & Poets and The NSAA Report. I'm also provide sound at The Brickhouse Art Gallery for some of their events.  

I love what I do and I want to keep doing what I do--only better. I want to take my promotion of the art and black community here in Sacramento to the next level but I need your help to do this. I need better equipment and resources.

Every year I do a fundraiser for my birthday to upgrade my capabilities. This year’s fundraiser is a bit more ambitious but I know we can do it.  

In 2010 I did a night of poetry and music called Poet Vs. Band for the now ended "In The Flow Festival" a festival celebrating improvisational music established by Ross Hammond. He asked me to do a poetry night and what I came up with is a night of music and poetry fusion. It went so well I did a couple more. I decided to resurrect the format for my birthday. What better way to celebrate my birthday but with night of poetry and music. Which are my passion. 

Art for me is that thing we all live for. It makes us feel better, it makes us reflect, it reveals more about ourselves. It is something we pass down to the next generation. We not only past down our knowledge but we also pass down how we see the world. I want to be part of that archiving. It is important that we capture not just the broad stokes of Sacramento but also its underground. 

With your help, I can obtain some of the equipment needed to do the above. This year my personal goal is $1500 (although the indigogo is set to my wish amount of 2,500). 1,500 should get the new laptop I desperately need. But if more is raised that would further my capabilities. And if less is raised that is okay too. Below are the achievement benchmarks.   

 

“If Then” Benchmarks

1. If $250 then Soundboard

2. If $550 then Soundboard + Video Card

3. If $1500 then Laptop

---------- Dream Treshold -----------

4. If $2500 then Soundboard + Laptop + Video Card

5. If $3500 then All of the above + Camera

story:
I would like to purchase an archival printer for my studio space so I can control my own print making and sales. I depend on a print-on-demand service currently, and while the quality is good, I'd like to maintain artistic control. This would enable me to do limited runs, signed editions, hand retouches, and multiple colorways of my works. I would like to purchase an Epson R2000 printer and back up set of archival inks. I will offer one of two prints to choose from to every person who graciously helps fund this campaign!

Feel free to look at my work on instagram @carolfarnumart or at facebook.com/carolfarnumartist

story:
Artist Statement

bristol hayward-hughes, born Seattle 1992, studied at Cornish College of the Arts, receiving a BFA in 2015. She works primarily in silkscreen printmaking, appropriated photography and video. Her works are conceptually based, mixed media collage that alludes to cultural, spiritual, and mythological representation of the feminine. Focusing of the depiction of the female as the beauty and the monster, she is inspired by Florentine depictions of the wrath of woman, glittering swatches of costume dress, an over saturated floral yet plastic palette to pile together and create an assemblage of explosive Pop color and materials of the modern future and the beauty of the past.

What I Need 

To prepare for my BFA show opening, opening May 8th, 2015. I really need some funds. I have been exhausting every resource I currently have and it's not quite enough. First I need to print and then I will need to frame, both take a lot of upfront resources. In addition to that I will be binding a limited run of 20 hand silkscreened zines that will be for sale at the show. Then there are all the little things like business cards to hand out and gloves so people will be able to leaf though my pages of work. 

What You Get

$1 will get you a handmade thank you card

$15 will get you a few silkscreened stickers

$20 will get you a silkscreened print from my BFA collection

$30 will get you a silkscreened tote-bag or t-shirt  

$45 will get you a silkscreened sweatshirt

$100 will get you a special prize 


& lastly an open invitation to come to the show at 2000 Lenora St. Seattle, WA on Friday, May 8th, 2015 

plz come and thank you so much for taking a peek

story:
THANK YOU FOR HELPING LEXI BELLA REACH AND EXCEED HER GOAL!!!

 

Help Lexi Bella To Paint Murals & Exhibit in Miami!

      Lexi Bella is one of the top street artists in New York City. She has won N.E.A. Grants to do social justice murals, painted Yankees at Yankee Stadium, traveled to Europe to win Art Battles, and been featured on Project Runway as inspiration for a winning design.

      Lexi has already purchased the tickets and booked an unrefundable  place to stay however LAST MINUTE A BACKER PULLED OUTAND NOW SHE IS AT A LOSS! HELP LEXI BE ABLE TO FULFILL HER OBLIGATIONS IN MIAMI AS WELL AS PAY RENT AND SUPPORT HER CHILD! Lexi Bella is also a single mother supporting herself and her daughter in the big Apple! When planning for this trip she purchased her tickets & room under the agreement with a client that she would complete a mural for them in exchange for funding the costs of the trip. This client has canceled leaving Lexi in an extremely unfortunate bind! BUT YOU CAN HELP AND GET COOL GEAR OR PRESENTS FOR THE HOLIDAYS AT THE SAME TIME!

What Lexi Needs & What You Get:

Breakin it down for folks in more detail:

Lexi Bella is asking for $2,000 to cover all costs associated with my trip to Miami from Sept 30- Dec 4th 2016. Lexi Bella is a fulltime artist & art educator and a mother to a 5 year old girl ( so she has an extra person to take care of as well!) She REALLY NEEDS YOUR HELP to grow as an artists and to spread the messages of social justice and public art THIS DECEMBER

Here is the break down of costs:

  • Air Travel roundtrip from NYC to Miami $320
  • AirBnB accomodations from Sept 30-Dec 4 $422
  • Transportation & car rental:$258
  • Paint & Supplies for 10ft X 10ft mural:$500
  • Food, Gas, Hydration:$400
  • Ladders:$100

PERKS:

  • $20 Gets You an Original Lexi Bella TShirt - you pick from 3 designs & sizes!
  • $40 Gets You an Original Lexi Bella Hoodie- you pick from 3 designs & sizes!
  • $100 Gets you a Lexi Bella Hoodie 3 Pack featuring all designs in size of your choice! ( You may also specify if you would prefer Tshirt 3 Pack!)
  • $150 Gets you an Original 12' X 12' Lexi Bella Painting hand painted and shipped to wherever you and your walls are!
  • $500 Gets you your own Lexi Bella Wall On Your Property, in your apartment, house, or on your businesses gate! You get a consultation on your design and then she will come to your place and create it before your very eyes! You may also select this option for a 10X10 painting on canvas if you prefer or need to have it shipped to you!
  • $1000 You get to decide what Lexi Bella's Bushwick Collective Miami mural will be! Lexi will consult you by phone or in person if possible and you will pick one of 5 Images she has prepared for references for the trip! Your Name will also be included prominently on mural! (Id you so desire)
  • All contributors names will be featured in all murals as a sign of gratittude!

SO HELP LEXI BELLA AND GAIN SOME FRESH GEAR OR ORIGINAL ART! GREAT PRESENTS FOR YOURSELF,OTHERS,AND GREAT CONTRIBUTION TO ONE OF NYCS LEADING ARTISTS!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • PLEASE SHARE THIS ON ALL SOCIAL MEDIA! HELP SPREAD THE WORD!
  • CALL LEXI BELLA IF YOU WANT MORE INFORMATION ON HOW TO HELP!
  • 856-816-3721

story:
Pre-order SPOON | 04

Help Us to keep this magazine ad-free and really independent


What is SPOON Magazine?

SPOON is an ad-free, fine-Art and slow fashion photography magazine. Originally created in 1996 as one of the first fashion Internet publication, we printed our first special edition that same year. After 7 issues, we left the company when the commercial protocol started to conflict with our creative goals and values. We recently re-purchased the SPOON magazine trademark, and right away, we relaunched and first issue of the new edition was born in early 2014.


Breaking free from the advertising pollution and feeling happier

The biggest decision we made when re-starting SPOON was to make a completely ad-free magazine because we felt this was the only way to keep our publication independent, and free from commercial pressure.

Since repurchasing, we’ve printed only with the help of the pre-orders on Indiegogo: we have no other revenues but sales and pre-orders. When the fixed goal for previous issues was not reached, we paid from our own, along with help from some generous friends. We won’t complain about it. This is our choice! We know that SPOON cannot be as independent, daring and free  if we take money from advertisers. We believe there is a strong future for a reader funded magazine like ours.

As we always gave freedom to our contributors, we give you the freedom to reflect and get inspired with no advertising interference of any kind.


Ready to roll !

We already have produced the brand new content for SPOON | 04, and we cannot wait to present it to you! To get the magazine launched for end of April 2016, we just need a little bit of help to fund the final phase: the printing and shipping of the magazines

3,500 € is our goal for this issue. Every bit of money donated, will be going towards the intended cause. Any excess of our goal will go directly into funding our next issue,so that we can raise the production value of our contents and pay for our contributors expenses appropriately.

Please, check out this fantastic line-up of artists curated from around the world for this issue: Lars Botten, Marcel Boudan,  Patrice Fuma Courtis, Peter C. Christensen,Emmanuel Gimeno, Steve Hiett, Andrew Lyman, Ollie Ma', Andreï Molodkin, Stephen Rose, Sanna Saastamoinen-Barrois, and many more . Visit our site or to discover all previous issues or visit our Ello profile to see what's coming in the next issue.



SPOON x Ello

In this issue we will publish a portfolio of talented emerging fashion artists that we kindly curated with and from Ello.co,  and exclusive interviews of the founders of this ad-free, ethical and beautifully minimal social network. When we discovered Ello, we knew we’d found a kindred spirit with their ad-free and human-centered values.


The one copy we print is the one for you

We have chosen to print digitally: that means, we print only the number of issues we need to print, that way we are sure there is no waste of printed copies, and no trees get chopped down  in vain! Only this technology allows us to continue to publish printed magazines with an ethical behavior.

This way you can order easily from anywhere, at anytime from our online shop and get it directly in your mailbox.

Pre-order, funding and deals!

Making a magazine is always for us an act of love and dependent upon the support of many others. Our goal is to make something you will want to own and keep, a collector's item you'll cherish.

However, we're not just appealing to your charitable side, but to your self-interest too. By contributing to this campaign, you're supporting the printing of SPOON by pre-ordering your copy without shipping fees or choosing to do a little donation by buying one of the fantastic offers we will add during this pre-ordering campaign.



Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about our campaign! The key to the success of this project is in those who are enthusiastic about SPOON, so don't be shy: we are open to any ideas you would want to share with us contact us at [info@spoon-publishing.com] with any questions or comments or proposals.

We'll make sure we go into production as soon as possible. However, if the goal above is not met, we will still produce the magazine as we always did !


Again, thank you very much

Karine Chane Yin + Patrice Fuma Courtis

Founders of SPOON Magazine


Follow us on :

   


Our offers

Make sure to come back in a few days, more offers will be available very soon...

6 Euros 
Show your love to SPOON !
You will get a public thank you on our social media pages
and you will get a link to download our last issue digital version.

19 Euros 
pre order SPOON | 04
You'll be one of the first people to hold SPOON in your hands, even before it hits the shelves of the bookstores
shipping costs included

39 Euros
will get you SPOON | 03 + SPOON | 04
shipping costs included

49 Euros
will get you
SPOON | 02 +03 + SPOON | 04
shipping costs included

69 Euros will get you 
all magazines produced since we have restarted SPOON = 01+02+03+04
shipping costs included

story:
Help Create a New Public Kinetic Art Exhibition Space

Artspace gallery in Richmond, VA, and VCUarts, Department of Kinetic Imaging, invite you to join us in the creation of a new public kinetic art exhibition space.

Help us activate our neighborhood in the Manchester community with the installation of a daylight visible, rear-projection screen, mounted inside the Artspace office window, at 31 E. 3rd St.  A high-quality laser projector will illuminate the screen from inside, and will be visible to the public along E. 3rd St. during both day and night time exhibitions.

Animations and short video will be provided by current and past students of VCU's Kinetic Imaging as well as professional video artists from Richmond and beyond. Students will also help curate the kinetic exhibitions and offer technical assistance in the start up phase of the project.

About Artspace

Artspace is an artist-run, non-profit gallery for the visual and performing arts located in Richmond, VA. Artspace promotes the understanding and awareness of contemporary art.

Founded in 1988, Artspace has provided a place for 1000's of visual artists of all media to showcase their work in a professional gallery environment. Since 2004, Artspace has occupied a 3000+ sq. ft. space in the Plant Zero Art Center, a renovated industrial building in Richmond's Manchester district.

Artspace features work in all mediums by emerging and established artists, from Richmond and beyond in exhibitions selected by our artist members from our open submission process. Artspace hosts Opening Receptions for new exhibitions on Fourth Fridays from 7-10pm and Artist Talks at 2pm on shows' closing dates. Visit us online at artspacegallery.org and in person at the gallery, Tuesday through Sunday, noon to 4 pm. Opening Receptions, Artist Talks and Regular Gallery Hours are all free and open to the public.

To expand its audience and further its mission Artspace is reaching out to the community beyond its doors and walls. The Public Kinetic Art Exhibition Space will feature a continuing series of exhibitions of kinetic art; including video, animation and film in a publicly visible space. Artspace's partnership with VCUarts Department of Kinetic Imaging will provide initial technical and curatorial assistance as well as a vast selection of imagery to display.  Once the public space is established, the gallery will extend its public calls for exhibition proposals to include videos for display in this new space.

About the VCUarts Department of Kinetic Imaging

VCUarts Department of Kinetic Imaging is a program dedicated to video, sound, and animation art.

VCUarts Historical and contemporary definitions of these media are reexamined in the context of ever-evolving media theory and technological possibilities. Students engage in multiple modes of expression with an emphasis on empowering their unique, artistic voice. Student work may include abstract, narrative, documentary, and the poetical. Tools of choice range from low-tech explorations to hi-tech. Media used encompass a broad range including 3D computer graphics, hand-drawn imagery, interactive environments, sound recording and composition, and hi-def video.

Students develop the technical skills required for professional work in a variety of media industries, but more importantly learn critical thinking and observation, creative self-expression, and the application and significance of media being defined in the digital age.

The Kinetic Imaging faculty members are professional, internationally recognized artists who are actively engaged in their work and the ongoing critical discussions in their fields.

About the project

A rear projection screen will be placed over the inside of Artspace's office windows that look out onto E. 3rd Street. This large set of windows measures 9x14 ft. The screen will be semi-permeable to allow light to come inside. A high quality laser projector will be mounted inside and will project onto the back of the screen, making the video visible from outside the gallery.

The use of a laser to project instead of a traditional bulb will extend the life and quality of the projector by 10x, reducing waste and cost over the duration of the project.

Work will be displayed by local film makers and VCU students studying the kinetic arts of video, and animation. This program will offer a new venue for makers of short films and animations and will expand the gallery's number of exhibition spaces and its ability to accommodate the growing field of video artists. The program will activate the public space outside of Artspace's East 3rd Street entrance as well as the industrial Manchester community at large with a living, changing mural.

How funds will be used

A custom made rear projection screen will be sized to fill the office window and a laser projector will be mounted to shine onto the inside of the screen. The devices chosen are required to allow for projection during daylight hours. Funds are needed to pay for the costs of the screen and projector, and for modifications made to the lights inside the office space to allow for a clear projection path.

Major components of the project are listed here:

CHIEF KITPD003W: Projector Mt kt RPAUW, CMS003W, CMS115W $194.63

DA-LITE 215509C HOLO: 106.25" x 170" Custom Size HOLO Screen for digital signage $14,512.50

ONYX-PARTS FREIGHT: Freight $350

SONY VPLFHZ60/W: 5000 lm WUXGA Laser Light Source 3LCD, White $6,355.33

SONY VPLLZ3009: SONY : 0.85-1.0:1 Lens for FH30/FHZ60 series PJ $2,037.35

Misc. Parts Adjustment: $351.75

Screen installation Labor: $2,944.03

Electrical materials and labor: $1,100

Sub Total: $27,846

Campaign Fees and Costs: $3,154

Total: $31,000


How this project was identified

During a strategic planning session in 2015, the members of Artspace identified the need to reach out and engage our local community over the next several years. Artspace’s location inside the Plant Zero Art Center makes it difficult for visitors to find us, and keeps us hidden from the public at large. The members decided that we needed to make our street entrance at 31 East 3rd Street more visible to encourage new patrons to come inside. The Public Kinetic Art Exhibition Space will give Artspace much needed visibility and deliver enticing visual displays that will peak the public’s curiosity, encouraging them to come inside to learn more about the project and other exhibitions on view inside the gallery.

Why this project is innovative

Projection displays have long been limited to night time performances due to the highly specialized equipment needed for day-light viewing. By providing these displays during the daytime, Artspace is creating a new way for the public to experience kinetic art during breaks from their work and on their way to and from their homes. Visitors to Richmond will have a new fine art attraction to explore during their daytime adventures around the river and in the Shockoe Slip and Bottom. Moving image art tends to be more accessible to the general public, creating a non-intimidating first impression of the gallery. This will encourage people to come inside to get more information about the public art on view and to gain exposure to the other more traditional work that is frequently exhibited inside, making a big impact on the gallery's ability to promote the understanding and awareness of contemporary visual and performance art.

Site of the project

The site of the Public Kinetic Art Space will be the street level window at the 31 E. 3rd St. entrance of Artspace. Artspace is located in the Manchester district of Richmond, in a rapidly growing area of urban renewal. According to the Richmond Times-Dispatch, in an article titled "Momentum gathering speed as Manchester springs back to life" published on Wednesday, March 19, 2014, "About 3,700 apartments have been built in Manchester in the past 10 years and 1,200 more are under construction..."

Artspace's neighbors on E. 3rd Street include the Plant Zero Cafe and the offices of Style Weekly. Artspace's location in Industrial Manchester is within easy walking distance of an older, under-served neighborhood that will also benefit from the display. East 3rd Street is a route commonly used by vehicular traffic going to and from Hull Street to I-95's Maury St. Exit.

The site is near numerous Richmond attractions like the new RVA street Art Festival Site at the Southern States Silos, the Floodwall Walk, Canal Walk, Cap to Cap Bike Trail, Shockoe Bottom and Shockoe Slip.

Impact on the community

The program will activate the public space outside of Artspace's East 3rd Street entrance as well as the industrial Manchester community. The public art display in our East 3rd Street window will increase the public's awareness of contemporary art and encourage their understanding of the work through information and literature available inside the gallery and on our website.

The Public Kinetic Art Exhibition Space will benefit students and artists involved in the display of their work as well the general public of the Manchester community. Watch video examples of work from VCUarts Department of Kinetic Imagery.

In the words of Pamela T. Turner, Chair of the VCUarts Department of Kinetic Imaging:

"The department of Kinetic Imaging has a comprehensive curriculum that covers video, animation, sounds, emerging media and the many hybrids and extensions of those areas. All students in the BFA program get a solid foundation in video, sounds, and animation production. The curriculum allows flexibility, enabling students to focus on an area or to create a cross-disciplinary art practice. It is critical that our students make art and media work that is meaningful, are able to make meaningful analysis and evaluation, attain a high level of electronic and digital media technical skills, and are professionally prepared upon completion of their degree.

This partnership [with artspace will] support these professional development goals [for the students] as they work outside of the classroom to apply their critical skills, and present their work to a public audience. They will gain invaluable experience working with a gallery such as Artspace to expand the offering of digital and electronic media arts . . . It is critical for the department to have this relationship as outreach into the community and to ensure that we contribute to the ongoing art welfare of the larger community. This work has the potential for inspiring under-served segments of our community, providing an accessible place to learn about kinetic artwork."


Goals and objectives

The primary audience will be the general public – both the growing local population as well as nearby residents from previously existing under-served neighborhoods in the Manchester area. Artspace wants to activate the under-served Manchester community by engaging residents and visitors with the goal of encouraging them to come inside and learn more about the kinetic display as well as other forms of contemporary art on view inside the gallery.

This project creates a Public Art Exhibition venue destination which will activate and engage the community as a whole, including the growing population of urban dwellers flocking to the new residential locations in Manchester as well as nearby residents from lower income neighborhoods. The program has the potential of inspiring this under-served segment of society to learn about and create kinetic artwork, providing new avenues of creative expression.

What if we don't reach our funding goal?

Artspace and VCUarts Department of Kinetic Imaging are dedicated to raising funds for this project. If total funding isn't met, we will first allocate donations towards the lighting renovations required in the office and next towards the purchase of the laser projector. The projector can be used in other places both inside and outside of the gallery providing exhibition space while we continue to fund raise for the custom screen.

More than we need?

In addition to this Indiegogo Campaign, Artspace has submitted grant proposals to the Virginia Commission for the Arts and CultureWorks Richmond for a total of $32,500. Award announcements from these proposals are due at the beginning of summer. If we are awarded grant money and/or raise more funds than needed, we will purchase a sound system for outside/inside use to go with the video aspect of the exhibitions, pay for professional design services for the office renovation and provide stipends for artists, technical assistants, and curators.
story_txt:
Help Create a New Public Kinetic Art Exhibition Space
Artspace gallery in Richmond, VA, and VCUarts, Department of Kinetic Imaging, invite you to join us in the creation of a new public kinetic art exhibition space.Help us activate our neighborhood in the Manchester community with the installation of a daylight visible, rear-projection screen, mounted inside the Artspace office window, at 31 E. 3rd St.  A high-quality laser projector will illuminate the screen from inside, and will be visible to the public along E. 3rd St. during both day and night time exhibitions.Animations and short video will be provided by current and past students of VCU's Kinetic Imaging as well as professional video artists from Richmond and beyond. Students will also help curate the kinetic exhibitions and offer technical assistance in the start up phase of the project.About Artspace
Artspace is an artist-run, non-profit
gallery for the visual and performing arts located in Richmond, VA.
Artspace promotes the understanding and awareness of contemporary
art. 


Founded in 1988, Artspace has provided
a place for 1000's of visual artists of all media to showcase their
work in a professional gallery environment. Since 2004, Artspace has
occupied a 3000+ sq. ft. space in the Plant Zero Art Center, a
renovated industrial building in Richmond's Manchester district.

Artspace features work in all mediums by emerging
and established artists, from Richmond and beyond in exhibitions
selected by our artist members from our open submission process. Artspace hosts Opening Receptions for
new exhibitions on Fourth Fridays from 7-10pm and Artist Talks at 2pm
on shows' closing dates. Visit us online at artspacegallery.org and
in person at the gallery, Tuesday through Sunday, noon to 4 pm.
Opening Receptions, Artist Talks and Regular Gallery Hours are all
free and open to the public.

To expand its audience and further its
mission Artspace is reaching out to the community beyond its doors
and walls. The Public Kinetic Art Exhibition Space will feature a
continuing series of exhibitions of kinetic art; including video, animation and
film in a publicly visible space. Artspace's partnership with VCUarts
Department of Kinetic Imaging will provide initial technical and curatorial
assistance as well as a vast selection of imagery to display.  Once the public space is established, the gallery will extend its public calls for exhibition proposals to include videos for display in this new space.
About the VCUarts Department of Kinetic ImagingVCUarts Department of Kinetic Imaging is a program dedicated to video, sound, and animation art.VCUarts Historical
 and contemporary definitions of these media are reexamined in the 
context of ever-evolving media theory and technological possibilities. 
Students engage in multiple modes of expression with an emphasis on 
empowering their unique, artistic voice. Student work may include 
abstract, narrative, documentary, and the poetical. Tools of choice 
range from low-tech explorations to hi-tech. Media used encompass a 
broad range including 3D computer graphics, hand-drawn imagery, 
interactive environments, sound recording and composition, and hi-def 
video.Students develop the technical skills required for 
professional work in a variety of media industries, but more importantly
 learn critical thinking and observation, creative self-expression, and 
the application and significance of media being defined in the digital 
age.The Kinetic Imaging faculty members are professional, 
internationally recognized artists who are actively engaged in their 
work and the ongoing critical discussions in their fields.About the project
A rear projection screen will be placed
over the inside of Artspace's office windows that look out onto E.
3rd Street. This large set of windows measures 9x14 ft. The screen
will be semi-permeable to allow light to come inside. A high quality
laser projector will be mounted inside and will project onto the back
of the screen, making the video visible from outside the gallery. The use of a laser to project instead of a traditional bulb will extend 
the life and quality of the projector by 10x, reducing waste and cost 
over the duration of the project. Work will be displayed by local film makers and VCU students studying the
kinetic arts of video, and animation. This program will offer
a new venue for makers of short films and animations and will expand
the gallery's number of exhibition spaces and its ability to
accommodate the growing field of video artists. The program will
activate the public space outside of Artspace's East 3rd Street
entrance as well as the industrial Manchester community at large with
a living, changing mural.


How funds will be used

A custom made rear projection screen
will be sized to fill the office window and a laser projector will be
mounted to shine onto the inside of the screen. The devices chosen
are required to allow for projection during daylight hours. Funds are
needed to pay for the costs of the screen and projector,
and for modifications made to the lights inside the office space to allow for
a clear projection path.Major components of the project are listed here:

story:
(detail) Little Dark Age by Miki Straus

In late 2018, four MGMT fans met in a little dark corner of the Internet also known as Facebook Messenger. They were all illustrators, and it didn't take them long to come up with the idea of paying homage to one of their favourite bands through art – a medium of expression so integral to the band's aesthetic and stage presence. Now, after five months of toil and trouble, a child of pen, ink, and paper is born. Behold, the MGMT Greatest Hits fanzine – featuring 24 illustrations based off MGMT's best-loved tracks, fresh off the press and straight from our hearts.

 

(detail) TSLAMP by EJ Oakley

We are four artists based in different corners of the world who, like many others, have been brought together by a mutual love of music and the arts. We've all worked very hard to give life to these pieces; fighting essay deadlines, thesis submissions, and gruelling overtime shifts to bring you this zine. If you're a fan of MGMT's music too, we hope you find wonder (and perhaps humour, too) in our interpretation of their work – and even if you're not a fan, we hope you like the art in itself!

The illustrators:

EJ Oakley (me!) is a freelance illustrator, graphic designer and concert photographer based in London, England. They are currently finishing up their final year of law school at University College London, and hopes to pursue a Masters degree in art after a year off from studying. Like most other MGMT fans, their favourite track is Siberian Breaks.

((As the creator of the fanzine, I will be overseeing the campaign and fulfilment/delivery of rewards.))

Miki Straus is a mixed media cartoon-and-game-maker based in Chicago, Illinois, who graduated from Maryland Institute College of Art in 2018 with a degree in animation. Miki's favorite track is Brian Eno, because it sounds spooky, but that's closely followed by Little Dark Age, because it sounds spooky.

Milo Best is an illustrator and animator from Dallas, Texas, who has just finished his senior year at the Maryland Institute College of Art. He hopes to move out to LA with his sister after graduating and find work in an animation studio! He can't decide what his favorite MGMT song is, but his favorite album is Congratulations. Actually, after thinking about it for 2 seconds he decided it's a four way tie between It's Working, Of Moons Birds and Monsters, An Orphan of Fortune and When You Die, but even then, there's so many more he really likes...

Yolande Leong is an illustrator and graphic designer based in Singapore. She is a graduate from Lasalle College of the Arts (Goldsmiths UOL) and is a brand designer by day. Yolande's favourite MGMT track is Siberian Breaks.

The band:

MGMT are an indie rock band formed by Andrew VanWyngarden and Ben Goldwasser in 2002. Any and all lyrics quoted in our illustrations remain the intellectual property of their rightful owners, and no copyright infringement of their work is intended.

 

(detail) It's Working by Milo Best

The zine will be A5 in size, staple-bound, and 32 pages from cover to cover, and will include 24 illustrations over 25 pages. We will be printing the contents on 150gsm glossy paper, and the cover on 170gsm matt laminated paper.

The full tracklist:

((Note: This is not the actual order in which pieces in the zine will appear.))

EJ Oakley: Electric Feel, Siberian Breaks (centre-spread), Your Life Is A Lie, TSLAMP, One Thing Left To Try, Hand It Over, cover art

Miki Straus: Weekend Wars, Flash Delirium, Brian Eno, Alien Days, Little Dark Age, James

Milo Best: Kids, The Youth, Of Moons, Birds and Monsters, It's Working, Mystery Disease, When You Die

Yolande Leong: Time To Pretend, Future Reflections, Congratulations, Cool Song No. 2, She Works Out Too Much, Me and Michael

Some samples (of the coming fun):

Current progress:

At this time of writing, we have collectively finished 21 out of the 24 pieces that will be in the zine. As the zine's layout will just consist of fully-sized pieces, it won't take much longer to put everything together (along with a contents page and artist biographies). We fully expect to be able to ship everything by mid to late June, although we've put July 2019 down for delivery as a contingency, just in case something goes drastically wrong at some stage in the process – we would rather fulfil ahead of schedule than behind!

 

(detail) Congratulations by Yolande Leong

Costs:

£400 - We hope to assign ourselves a payment of £100 each for our work. This will increase or decrease in proportion to however much of our campaign goal we manage to raise.

£700 - The cost of printing the zines and art prints, and of shipping them out internationally (from the United Kingdom). We will be sending you any physical zine copies and art prints via Royal Mail First Class International Tracked delivery, which has an average delivery time of 5 to 7 working days – the fastest delivery options available! All shipping costs are already included in the tier prices, so you won't receive any unpleasant additional surprises when checking out.

£200 - Indiegogo platform fees, card fees, and buffer.

Rewards:

((NOTE: International shipping is included in the price of every tier including a physical reward – you will not have to pay extra upon checkout.))

TSLAMP – £5:

A digital copy of the zine that'll only set you back a fiver. May increase your TSLAMP if you're reading on the go, or you could view it on a laptop or desktop in all its hi-res glory.

Mockup of the physical zine

Electric Feel – £15:

Not many things feel more electrifying than the sensation of glossy paper on your fingertips. This tier gets you a physical copy of the zine mailed straight to your doorstep.

Cool Song No. 2 – £20:

You might feel better knowing your zine isn't alone in that little envelope heading your way. Get an A5, matt-laminated art print of one of the above four works alongside it too with this reward tier! Choose your print in the options available at checkout.

Bubblegum Dog – £25:

Thankfully we can assure you that this reward tier is a lot less mysterious than the whereabouts of the Bubblegum Dog studio recording. Pledge £25 or more and you'll get both a digital AND physical copy of the zine, as well as ALL FOUR A5 art prints listed above.

Siberian Breaks (alternate edition) by EJ Oakley

Siberian Breaks – £30:

The biggest, the best, and (hopefully) the fan favourite. This tier gets you a digital AND physical copy of the zine, all four A5 art prints from the previous tier, AND a matt-laminated, 200gsm, A3 (!!) print of this alternate version of the zine's Siberian Breaks centre-spread. Yes, it no longer has text on it. Yes, you can gaze deeply into Andrew and Ben's eyes (if you so wish). And hell yes, you can mount this on your wall.

Yes, it no longer has text on it. Yes, you can gaze deeply into Andrew and Ben's eyes (if you so wish). And hell yes, you can mount this on your wall.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Josh Zeis. I am a veteran and an artist based out of Fargo, ND. I have been working with a National Endowment for the Humanities funded grant to document veteran's stories called Project Unpack. After two years of amazing and meaningful work, we came to a point were we need to obtain more funding to continue our documentation.
  • So in the meantime I am casting a net to see what I can catch. I wasn't sure if I would be selected to go to this workshop, but it happened and now I really need to go. I wasn't able to budget this since it wasn't a sure thing and came up quick. I feel that this event is crucial for the work we have done for the last couple years and the work we will do moving forward. I have this wonderful opportunity to meet and brainstorm with amazing veteran artists from all over the country with the intention of expanding Project Unpack. 
  • Also, I get to take my Army fatigues with me and turn them into paper! These days I am all about moving forward!!!

What We Need & What You Get

  • These funds go to cover airfare ($790) and the rest to cover my butt since this is unpaid leave from my full time job! 
  • Those who fund $40 or more will receive a set of two ceramic coffee mugs made by me with a personal tag made from paper that was once my combat uniform! 
  • Those who fund $150 or more will get a set of mugs and a 12"x 12" intaglio print from my latest exhibition at the Plains Art Museum. 

The Impact

  • This workshop will not only strengthen my creative skills as a maker, it will also forge a supportive community through transformation.
  • Project Unpack has documented so many veterans stories through oral narration, written stories, and visual stories through clay and mask making. On my end of the project, the visual end, there is something about craft that calls out to veterans and it's difficult to pinpoint what that is. I hope that I find an answer to that at Haystack!
